values:
But also I've suddenly felt an overwhelming sense of loss regarding HP fandom. I'm not in it anymore, haven't been for at least half a decade, but I never thought I'd see the day where I couldn't get in touch with fabulous people I met during my time in it. Emails bouncing and whatnot. 

If any of you on my friends list come across this post one day in your future please, please drop me a comment. I will always do my best to keep this account active (as you can see from by the gap between this post and the last). It's a piece of my history, a piece that I'm not necessarily ashamed of.

I'm on facebook and tumblr ( http://www.tumblr.com/blog/alittlestardustcaught). Look me up, guys. I'd love to reconnect with you special people again.

Sarah x

I have finished reading the 7th Harry Potter book and I will never read another new one again. And it hurts so badly. It was so... perfect. No book has made me go through the rollercoaster of emotions like this one did. I only finished reading twenty miutes ago and came straight to LJ. Although I haven't updated in more than a year, I read my friends list every time I came online, just to check up on you guys. I started this LJ because of Harry Potter fandom and it is fitting that I leave it as I have left the last Harry Potter book and hence, my childhood.

I probably won't update again. But I will continue to look at my friends list. This is my real goodbye. Thank you for all coming on this rare, once in a life time journey with me that has lasted years. I was a girl when I entered the HP universe and fandom and I'm now a woman, who has acheived much in my short amount of time. 

If you still want to keep in contact, I'm a regular on Facebook. Email me and I'll give you my real name if you have an account there.

Thanks guys. For everything.

Ragggghhhh.

Fractured toe. Oweeee and also very annoyed. No work or graduation performance rehearsals for me. 

Trust me to get so enthused I break something.

But no work today is good because it allows me to watch Doctor Who tonight... gearing myself up to wet my pants from fright. I also have to gear myself up to make the very painful walk to Boots to acquire some Ibupofen.

I've been absent from LJ a long time. Yeah, okay, there's been the odd 'poke your nose in' entry but to be quite honest they're pathetic compared to the time when it was an entry every two days. My assessments are over. This term is nearly over. This bitch from hell, scratch my eyes out, ears bleeding term. Thank fuck. But I have done things. I have started going to the cinema on my own, found RL Potter friends, met famous people and made leaps and bounds in my dance training. I just haven't been posting about them. I'm not going to miss college. I leave in July and I know I'm not going to look back on these years with fondness. I'll acknowledge they've been character building and made me a better dancer and given me a degree from a reputable institution but to be quite honest the college and everyone in it can go take a running jump because I've paid for those things I've just listed. God, I'm boring myself. In other news, just last week I met John Major, the Monarchy of Denmark, Jeremy Irons and Farmer Hoggett from Babe. :) And yes I've seen the Potter film. Extremely impressed but why, oh, why did I cry at a Potter film? Embarrassing, no?

Home for the weekend which meant I had unlimited time on the computer to watch the GoF premiere streaming. I only have a few things to say. 1. Dan is too jumpy and bubbly for my liking, he could learn a few things of of Rupert. 2. WTF was Emma wearing? Perhaps taking the vintage theme that's so popular this autumn a tad too far. 3. How gorgeous was Bonnie? I thought she beat Emma by far. 4. I want Katie Leung's dress. After two weeks of being AWOL doesn't this insightful and meaningful post make up for my absence? :) GoF tickets booked for the Leicester Square Odeon on Thursday the 24th of November to avoid the kiddie rush. Mwa ha ha ha, I will walk around all of Leicester Square tracing the imprints of the rich and Potter-famous, ha ha ha. Anyone seen the trailer for Narnia? So good. *drools*

Currently at home with the parents and brother after an emergency train ride home from London Thursday night.

I have flu and an ear infection. Woe.

No work, no college, lots of TV and cups of tea.

Good thing: can watch morning cartoons which means catching Harry Potter stuff, can doze on the sofa with feather pillows and duvet, can live in my pyjamas, no college, no work.

Bad things: Being in the above situation when neighbours make impromptu drop-in's to use toilet as they're having work done on their's this weekend. And stay for a cup of coffee.

Sore throat and bunged up ears = ouch. :(

Yes. Lazy, lazy, lazy.

I have been in London all of this summer doing SWEET FA. My work starts at seven in the evening so I've been waking at 2 in the afternoon and just basically pissed about watching a Place in the Sun and that kind of crappy telly.

I have been too lazy to get to an internet cafe (a three minute walk from me) to converse with you lot. Or even wax lyrical about my holiday in Monaco. Which I must do.

Excuse for the past four weeks... riveted to THE ASHES, BABY! About bloody time for the men's AND women's team. Don't forget the women's team. They've been without longer, haven't they? Since the sixties? Or did I hear wrong?

However, I have been doing class at half eight in the morning for the past week before college starts in two weeks. Am bleary eyed.

Going now as my bladder is full to bursting after drinking about two pints of coffee.

And to sign this post off with at least one regard to other people: I know it's late but I hope everyone on lj who got mixed up in Hurricane Katrina is ok. I don't really know what else to say or do about this as I don't want to put my foot in it. My thoughts are with you.

Flew in from Nice yesterday evening and immediately started on HBP. Just one comment below the tag.

<lj-cut text= "Yikes.">

After I finished the chapter on Dumbledore's death I think I heard my heart crack a little. If I remember correctly after OotP came out I said "I love Snape and want to have his babies."

Throughout today, I was still feeling a little bit sick about Snape's betrayal even after rationalising the that part of the plot. Really, I do have my head screwed on and I can agree that Snape and Dumbledore might have had a plan for emergencies, but my body took over and I couldn't stop feeling sick.

Loved the book though. So much better than OotP which I didn't think was awful.

</lj-cut>

Will try and join in with conversations about HBP but time is limited as I'm back in London tomorrow and starting work.

Hark at me coming back from a two week holiday in Monaco and I start talking Potter. Monaco was hot. And gorgeous. Will describe later.

Everyone at my college is perfectly healthy, although that seems ridiculously lucky considering we're situated between the Kings Cross and bus blasts.

Unfortunately a friend of a friend is missing presumed dead in the Kings Cross carnage.

Okay, it's half nine PM and I've finally been able to get to an internet cafe (the only "shops" in London that are currently open).

Yes, I'm fine, and yes, I managed to get caught up in it. I've spoken to my mum and dad quite a lot so I feel I can share. Here's the story.

Some of you may not know that my route to school is through Russell Square park and along the road in which the bus was destroyed. My college is thirty seconds from Kings Cross and the bus carnage, that's why I was using that road.

And of course I was on way to college at ten to ten this morning instead of the usual eight o'clock as I break up from college tomorrow.

I heard the sound of the blast when walking through Russell Square park, I was still walking along the road towards it a minute later as police had not arrived yet. I got within two hundred metres of the bus before being stopped by a line of police that had arrived from the blast in Russell Square. I saw bodies, blood on the white stone walls of buildings and of course a bus without it's roof but amazingly still with its seats intact. It smelt dirty and hot.

I froze taking in the scene before me and the next thing I knew a policeman had his arm around my shoulders while leading me to sit down on the kerb of a pavement further away. He said he'd come back later to check on me but I left after 30 seconds. He had things he had to get on with, he didn't need me getting in the way.

I still tried to get to college by most roads were cordoned of at that point and I was just being pushed further and further west. Thousand of people were all around me. Calm, silent people just walking. However nearly everyone had a mobile to their ear but weren't talking. I tried to ring my mum; I was cut off. I tried to ring my dad; I was cut off. Tried everyone. Network overload.

At this point I'm nearby Paddington trying to look for a payphone with a reasonably sized queue. An hour later I ended up finding one near Tottenham Court Road. I get hold of my dad; who starts crying. I get hold of my mum; who starts crying. Very shocking as my parents aren't the crying kind of people really.

I go back to my hostel, switch on the TV and suddenly burst into tears. I was angry, so, so, angry. I went back out, got a large latte and walked all over London. I walked to Buckingham Palace, Downing Street, Houses of Parliament and the London Eye. I walked for about 3 hours. No cars, no taxis, no buses. Just a lot of silent people. I've never seen London look so much like a ghost town. I've also been taking a lot of calls from friends and family so it's been a pretty busy day. I'm emotionally and physically drained. But I'm fine. It would have been a different story if I'd literally left my hostel five minutes earlier.

The people of London amazed me. I always thought that when an attack happened (and I always thought of 'when' not 'if') it would be alot of crazed individuals screaming their heads off. The complete opposite happens. I've heard of people criticizing the British 'stiff upper lip' before. But in this case it helped everything run along smoothly. That stiff upper lip was resilience. 

If anyone on the web has lost someone or has a love one in hospital due to these attacks, I'm thinking of you.

Term is nearly over and I have lots of pleasant things to look forward to. But not so much looking forward to the hospital appointment due in three weeks which is costing me ONE HUNDRED AND THIRTY POUNDS STERLING for 40 MINUTES. Note the expense that I cannot afford. Got my marks for the technique assessments and again got Firsts in three of the four marks I received. The one I didn't get a First in I am appealing against. Not because I didn't get a First but because it is just ridiculously low. 57%. That's scraping the barrel at a 2:2. That mark was not based on my dancing. So I've made an appointment to see my tutor and the Director. I WILL NOT GIVE IN TO THE BASTARDS. I'll let you know how it goes. Nowt else interesting. Just work, work, work. Have been working at Royal Theatre Drury Lane and Her Majesty's Theatre on Sundays for the past month. Double and a half time, people! Bye. I need to go holiday shopping and book my train home on Sunday. More expense. Whinge, whinge, whinge.

I'm going to Monaco for two weeks in July straight after I finish school. This means I miss the release of HBP. This sucks as I ordered it in January thinking I'll be there on the day and it's the day after my birthday yada yada yada. But honestly when it comes down to it I'd chose the holiday over the book because I bloody well deserve this holiday. I've been working my little cotton socks off this year at college and have been working at the theatre more hours per week than anybody else I know at college. Nothing else interesting. Dance is going well apart from The Injury From Hell but what can you do, eh? C'est la vie. Won't be updating too much around the summer holidays either because I've decided to stay in London and work, work, work. Look at me all grown up. (Oh, and just to change the subject, if anybody wants to read one of the best books ever [in my opinion, which is very harsh when it comes to books] pick up 'Five People You Meet in Heaven' by Mitch Albom. It was the most beautiful book I've every read. And 'The Crimson Petal and The White' by Michel Faber was pretty decent too.)

Just a quick drop-in.

Went for a walk about 10 yesterday morning and I was walking up Whitehall and saw all these people standing on the traffic islands.

"Stupid tourists" I thought, as I needed room on one of these islands to cross the road.

Got to an island and peered around the throng of people gathered there and saw a big brass band coming out of the Changing of the Guards place followed by hundreds of veterans in green berets.

It was a VE day march.

I followed them all the way up to the Mall and got a fantastic place by one of the barriers and three policeman in black uniform and helmet.

As they passed people in the mall, people started clapping and I just burst out crying. Luckily I had sunglasses in my bag so I put those on. 

I didn't stop crying for 45 minutes until the end of the ceremony.

I didn't expect to cry, especially as I was on my own in public, but I'm glad I did because it made my day. Marches like this just get to me. Particularly because of the music. It's the same reason I got emotional at the Queen Mother's funeral.

Had to write about that.

I've been watching the Pope's funeral occaisionally this morning mainly because there's nothing else on TV. Now, I understand that a Pope's funeral is more important that a Crown Prince's second wedding. I do. But when I see that only one person is separating that Crown Prince in the seating plan from Robert Mugabe... Are they taking the piss? The Vatican is currently reminding me of playground shit-stirrers. Sorry for ruffling any feathers but I'm slightly pissed off at the cheek of it.

Notice anything different?

*twirls*

No?

I'll give you a clue.

Broadband, baby.

OW, I HAVE A SPLINTER IN MY KNUCKLE AND IT GODDAMN HURTS!!!! In other news, I just like to report the fact that I am a macho, macho man. Turns out I broke my foot about two months ago and didn't even know. *flexes biceps* Oops, wrong part of the anatomy. *flexes foot* So shove that up your arse, all you suing-cos-I-tripped-over-a-spoon weaklings.

Pope John Paul II is dead. 

Religion has been a popular topic of discussion across our dinner table this week. Only on Thursday my Mum and I were talking for over an hour about what we believe (she's very spiritual about her religion, doesn't believe what the bible says but is still a Christian and I... can't, I suppose, believe in anything). I had the same discussion with my 17 year old, and rather Kevin-esque, brother yesterday.

I don't agree with the Roman Catholic faith as it is and I found the late Pope to have very simple views that just do not work in todays modern age of promiscuity and disease. 

But I understand his death is an important event. I may not feel anything rather than a detached interest but the historian in me doffs its cap at the passing of the pontiff. Because I'm here and I'm witnessing and what else can a non-believer do?

It's Easter Monday and I am throwing a mope because my brother is forcing me to watch Digimon when I wanted to watch Pokemon. :( Yes, I'm home. Home after a bitch of a journey on Friday when I was on my train in Paddington, the engine a-rumbling away, when the tannoy announces there's a lorry on the track and trains will not be coming in or out of Paddington. Had to go all the way to Waterloo and get an hour and a half train to READING (it usually takes me an hour and a half to get home) and, of course, because it was sucky Good Friday all the shops were closed on the platforms so I couldn't get breakfast. Mope, mope, mope. Popped into Radnorshire, Wales on Saturday for a lovely lunch and got fork 'andles. Well, actually it was three, but never mind. I'm going to see Peter Pan with Northern Ballet Theatre at Sadler's Wells next week. Fun. Let's hope they're restricting the cheese. And now I will be online until something interesting happens to me.

So... I got the best marks in Contemporary and Ballet that I've ever had, I've been working all the hours that God sends and I think I'm finally ready to go homehomehome. Didn't get to watch much of Comic Relief but Patrick Stewart and Joshua Jackson took their bow with painted red noses (I thought they looked like they had colds) and asked the audience to give generously in a speech where Mr Stewart corrected Mr Jackson for saying 'bills' instead of 'notes'. Well, when in Rome... Saw something about the top British films of 2004 in which Harry Potter 3 came first. Forgive my ignorance... but I thought that a British film is made with British money. It's not British if it uses British actors and location in Britain with foreign money. I've been reading too many books for my own good. Bought and read in the last three weeks: 1. My Sister's Keeper - Good 2. The American Boy - OK 3. The Time Traveler's Wife - Good. 4. One Child - Crap, crap, crap 5. The Curious Incident of The Dog in The Nighttime - it gave me headache. The language used gave me a headache and I had no sympathy for the character. At all. I kept thinking to myself, "If I had to deal with that kid, I'd walk away." But that reflects on me as a person, not the author as a writer. Michael Howard's an idiot for raising the idea of lowering the number of weeks for an abortion. Yes, I'm not a Labour supporter but I truly hope this man does not get voted in. Whatever happened to Tory leader's that had personalities? Bring Mr Hague back is what I say. Tony Blair's an idiot. Gerry Adams is not a nice man at all. But I'm proud enough to say that I've known this for as long as I've been interested in politics. This hasn't been realised in the past few months for me. And in a week's time I will be going home. Home to the sound of wind rustling through trees and the sound of the defiant fox hunter's trumpet. Yay!

10 Things I've Done That You Haven't. 1. Had my front tooth knocked out during a dance show. 2. Dance at the Royal Albert Hall in front of a packed audience. 3. Danced at Disney Land Paris. 4. Spoken to Joshua Jackson, Patrick Stuart, Geri Halliwell, Mackenzie Crook, Christian Slater, Dermot O'Leary, Michael Portillo, Ross Noble, Bill Bailey, Darius, Jamie Theakston, and many others within the last 6 months. 5. Auditioned successfully for all the dance schools I applied to. 6. Broken my wrist while playing tennis, carrying on the game and winning. :p 7. Holidayed in Boscastle two days before it was wiped out by the torrential flooding. 8. Joined a rave on the beach of the River Thames. 9. Had my school Leaver's Days (one every academic year) at Gloucester Cathedral aka the cloisters seen in the Harry Potter films. 10. Been asked to join modelling agencies 8 times within the past year and a half just by walking through the centre of London. One was Select. *grooms* Pretty good list, methinks.

Just skimmed through my flist and hit upon something that I can associate with. said she was feeling disconnected from her flist. I feel like that. I've felt like that for the past 3 months. I sometimes yearn for the days where I had the time and the creativity to think up something relatively interesting every two days. I went through my flist and I just didn't have anything to say in their comments section. MOAN. Nothing interesting happening. A lady had a miscarriage in the theatre on Saturday. She was distraught poor thing. Blood everywhere, I mean everywhere in the toilets. So much that we had to close it off for the following show. Spoke to Geri Halliwell on Wednesday. Once to tell her where the toilets were and the second time I said "jsbfosdonglnsofnosirnwenionf", also known as, "The Stage Manager is waiting for you by the private entrance". Sometimes Sarah trips over her words too fast. Assessments for the next three weeks. Again... MOAN. , did you get my xmas card? Sorry, a bit belated I know. I don't trust Royal Mail, you must tell me whether the eejits have lost it or not.

A quick update...

Went to the press party for A Life in the Theatre last night and got hammered on free Cosmopolitans. 

Saw Darius, Sophie Ellis Bextor, Jamie Cullum, the Swedish Crown Princess and Richard E. Grant.

Introduced myself to Joshua Jackson, said I was Front of House at the Apollo, he said he had seen me around.

Joshua Jackson has very soft hands and he is very tall.

Bad thing? Doing ballet at 8:45 in the morning with a hangover.

I have been very absent from LJ this past academic year. Not my fault, I can assure you. These new first years keep hogging the computers every bloody lunchtime. It's a good day if I can read my emails, let alone actually reply to them. News: I am injured again. My left hamstring has almost completely recovered from the year and a half it shutdown and now my right is playing up. This means I must make a trip along the yellow brick road to Winfield Sports Clinic in Gloucestershire. They have a hamstring specialist there who was part of the GB Olympic Physio team last year. It'll be nice to know I've got one of the top people in their field checking out my groin. :) In a purely anatomical meaning of the word. Last bit of news, which isn't really news. Now is the season for TV adverts promoting holidays, the most annoying one being the flying mermaid for Turkey. Does this happen in other countries? To promote tourism for Britain do they have flying Beefeaters? Perhaps Her Majesty flies while clutching a handbag and a corgi? Am curious. Also, while browsing IMDb I came across a bit of news that paused my hand on the mouse. Brad Pitt is campaigning to save Eastenders from being axed from American TV? WTF? Is this true?

A - Accent: Normal English accent with a soft, countrified lilt to it. B - Breast size: 34B/C C - Chore you hate: Washing up. D - Dad's name: Adrian E - Essential make-up item: Concealer. F - Favorite perfume: Not a fan of perfume. G - Gold or silver: White gold :). H - Hometown: Kings Stanley, Gloucestershire I - Insomnia: Most of the time. J - Job title: Student. K - Kids: Not just yet thanks. L - Living arrangements: A single room in a student hostel in London and my family home with mum, dad and bro in Gloucestershire. M - Mum's birthplace: Eltham, London N - Number of pets you've had: 1, a cat, she died when I was 4. O - Overnight hospital stays: Once. I was 2 and has suspected meningitus. P - Phobia: I don't think I have one. R - Religious affiliation: Church of England. But hey, isn't that your parents fault? I was 3 months old, I had no choice. S - Siblings: I brother. T - Time you wake up: Now I'm living closer to school: 7'o'clock. U - Unnatural hair colors you've worn: Dark red and in October a black base and light brown slices. V - Vegetable you refuse to eat: Suede, parsnips and suede. W - Worst habit: Not shutting up when I know I've crossed the line. X - X-rays you've had: 4 on my right wrist, 6 on my right ankle, 1 on my head, 2 on my left wrist and 3 on my teeth. Also an MRI scan. Y - Yummy foods you make: I don't make food. It comes to me sealed from Tesco's. Z - Zodiac sign: Cancer, I think. It an load of utter tosh, I tell you! There is no better way to bore me than to talk bloody star signs.
Bye, bye Busted.

Went to HMV a few days ago and got some DVD's.

I cannot stop watching the 'Peter Pan' (2003) film.

I love Peter Pan.

I love the boy who plays Peter Pan.

Peter Pan rocks my world.

I think someone mentioned the hotness of Peter Pan a few months ago but for the life of me I can't remember who it is.

Must stop watching Peter Pan. Watch 'The Pianist' to stop squeeing.

Britain has donated 60 million pounds of aid to the Tsunami Crisis compared to 50 million pounds of government aid.

We are second in the world for the amount of aid given only to America.

I am very proud of my country right now (which hasn't happened for a long, long time). Thank you for proving me wrong in thinking we're all selfish, moaning, suing, illiterate, pregnant <strike>chavs</strike>... er people.

*love spread all around*

Have been working solidly on my Feminist Criticism essay for the past few days. Research, research, research. If anybody has any questions about Marxist feminism, Poststructuralist feminism (Yay!), Eco feminism, Socialist feminism, Conservative feminism, Liberal feminism, Radical feminism, Anarcha feminism and Womanism... *breathes* ...please form a queue to the right. Now I've got to go write the bloody thing. Have a good New Year everybody. I will be playing Spoons aka Donkey aka The Card Game of Pain when midnight hits.

I'm not home between the 24th and the 27th as I'm going to Kent to visit family (*quiet groan*) and this means I'm missing someone's birthday. We haven't been in contact much this year due to busy schedules but I still consider her one of my oldest online friends. On the 26th of December she's catching me up in age and turning nineteen. (It's a grand old age, sweetheart, a grand old age). So, in advance,
"Happy Birthday ! Have a good day!
Harry Potter and the Half Blood Prince comes out on the 16th of July 2005! The day after my birthday!! Yaaaaaaayyyy!!!

Last day of term but I won't be able to check LJ or update until at least the 19th of December as I'm not going home straight away. I couldn't get the time off work. I had a few things that I wanted to say but I can't really remember what they were... Oh! I know. I worked at The Woman In White on Tuesday and it was shit. It reminded why I'm not fond of musicals. They can never walk anywhere. They have to run or trot everywhere. Apparently they think that's more dramatic. Wankers. Michael Crawford was the only good thing in it. But that's a given. He's fantastic anyway. And I was lucky enough to walk past him and give him a smile after the show while making my way to stage door. Music was crap, the staff were weird and the projected set got on my nerves. I longed for my little theatre called the Apollo. :) When I next update I will be home!! I haven't been home since the beginning of September!!! Countryside of Gloucestershire, here I come!

I do not like getting tapped on the shoulder. 

It feels extremely aggressive. Why bother with words when you have a tap on the shoulder?

So please, if ever you need to get my attention, never tap me on the shoulder.

Because made me. 1. When did you first "friend" me? 2. Why did you first "friend" me? 3. What posts of mine do you like to read the best? 4. What would you like me to write about that I don't? 5. Do you think we would be friends in real life? 6. How often do you read my journal? 7. What do we have in common? 8. Will you post this in your journal so I can answer? 9. If I were an HP character, who would I be?
Oh My God. I want and I need. Have added to wish list. *sobs* Oh Philippa Gregory! How you do tempt me so!

I had my ballet assessment yesterday morning. At quarter to nine in the morning. Bleargh.

It went pretty well but, unfortunately, during the last two exercises I got that medical thing where you can't feel your legs. They just felt like lead. Anyway, I had to do a really hard fuck off unseen exercise and a big jump exercise in front of 5 teachers with clipboards while my body goes through a breakdown.

Thank you so much arsey body. You really kick in at the best of times. >:(

Let just hope the other hour and a quarter of class kept my mark up. 

BOOOO!!!

But on a lighter note, my essay deadline has been extended from this Monday coming to the 4th of January. Bring it on.

Off to beat my legs with a club. But I might have to make do with a yoga mat.
Gacked from . Why I'm proud of britain.

Received PoA DVD via the lovely Amazon on Friday. Spent most of the weekend watching and then rewatching.

Have to say I slightly disappointed in the DVD extras. Can't say why. Maybe I was expecting more behind the scenes stuff.

Also, from looking at the photos from the DVD launch, I think Bonnie Wright has bloomed. I think she'd looks perfectly lovely and I also want her clothes. For a change, she outshone Emma Watson. Go, Bonnie!

Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason?

Not all that. The only good part was the ski slope incident. But maybe I'm being a bit too critical. Thinking about it, it would probably have been a good film (as in something I would like, not about camera shots and screenplay) if it had been a standalone ie there wasn't a prequel. 

But luckily Colin Firth was still dishy. Arrogantly dishy. Mmmm.

I quickly became annoyed when I got to my seat because I went to the Leicester Square Odeon, payed 13 quid for a ticket and then got put on the far right side of the Royal Circle. I like seeing the screen face on! Moan.

Oh. And because organised Sarah ordered in August through Amazon.co.uk, her PoA DVD comes to her 8am on Friday morning. Hee.

This is the problem with LJ: We all think we are so close, and we know nothing about each other. I'm going to rectify it. I want you to ask me something you think you should know about me. Something that should be obvious, but you have no idea about. Is there anything you don't know about me? Probably not. :)

Is it true that Americans have no idea what a mince pie is? Mince pies are christmas. Forget your gawdy trees and bits of shiny stuff. Also, today I held my two minute silence. I held it while I was alone while there was nobody to tell me to do it and I remembered. And although I respect people's opinions on nearly everything, I 'm not scared to say that I wear my poppy with pride. And I always will.

I had my first snub of my degree course yesterday. I was talking to a lady customer at work last night and she asked me what I studied. I told her. I got a very disdainful look. "Oh really?" she said. Now, I've never received a comment or look like that before when it's about my chosen field of study. Usually people, bless them, make a valiant effort to be interested and "amazed" that I'm doing a Degree in Contemporary Dance. So, if there are any people out there that are dubious about what I do, this is for you. Contemporary Dance Technique - every morning Ballet Technique - every morning DALI (Dance, Arts, Literature and Ideas) Body Conditioning Anatomy Human Biology Performance Studies Professional Studies History of Music Choreography Choreology Doublework Improvisation Design for Dance These are the subjects that I have to fit in the five days a week I have at school. These subjects are compulsory. If I don't turn up for one, I am marked as absent. I'm only allowed to miss 20% of classes each term. In some cases that means I'm allowed too miss two classes every 10 weeks. If I'm ill three times in a term, I'm fucked. Each subject is an hour and a half long and certain subjects we have to study twice a week. In the third year I have 10 other subjects to choose that aren't on this list.I'm at school from 8 in the morning and leave at 6 in the evening to go straight to work for half 6. My degree is vocational and therefore is worth more than a degree in English Literature or History because I'm learning a trade. So fuck you, lady.

I had enough time to read my flist (I haven't been at school for 5 days therefore no free broadband internet) but I now don't have enough time to reply to the posts. So here are some replies in speed...

<lj user="ari_o">, CONGRATULATIONS BOO! Keep us updated, sweetheart.

<lj user="bochup">, you go for the NaNoWriMoWhyIsThisNameSoWeird-o. You've got the talent to do it, just don't get stressed over it.
